Colin, I think a good benchmark problem for HyperNEAT is probably the "bo=
xes" domain described here:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2009/stan=
ley.alife09.html

It's a highly regular problem that any HyperNEAT implemen=
tation should be able to solve, and should be able to solve in a variety of=
 ways.

(The problem is to identify the location of a large box in a high-r=
esolution visual grid that also contains a small box.)

ken

--- In neat@ya=
hoogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> 2010/1/24 Ken <kst=
anley@...>
> >
> > Is the test harness also designed for HyperNEAT experime=
nts? For example, XOR isn't a typical benchmark for HyperNEAT (i.e.
> > its=
 network doesn't have regularities and is quite small). Also, it would need=
 to come with a HyperNEAT substrate for XOR. Is that
> > really the intent =
or is it more than there aren't really HyperNEAT-centric experiments at lea=
st at the moment?
> >
> 
> Yes so the test code that's in there currently b=
uilds a substrate for
> XOR on the basis that (A) I have known-to-be-workin=
g XOR code and (B)
> I already knew a minimal substrate for XOR - in was a =
quick way to
> test the code in totallity.
> 
> The harness builds a suitab=
le substrate and 'wires' it and various
> other components together, such a=
s a genome decoder, evaluator,
> speciation strategy and evolution algorith=
m. The problem domains are
> completely independent from NEAT or HyperNEAT =
so all you have to do to
> get an existing domain designed for NEAT to work=
 is build a substrate
> and switch to using the HyperNEAT genome decoder in=
stead of the Neat
> decoder.
> 
> BTW do you or anyone here have any ideas =
about what is a good baseline
> problem domain for HyperNEAT? sort of an eq=
uivalent to XOR in NEAT.
> 
> Colin
>
